verses.verse: The People Afraid of God’s Presence Now (Heb. 12:18, 19) all the people (Rev. 1:10, 12) witnessed the thunderings, the lightning flashes, the sound of the trumpet, and the mountain (Ex. 19:16, 18) smoking; and when the people saw it, they trembled and stood afar off.
Then they said to Moses, (Gal. 3:19; Heb. 12:19) “You speak with us, and we will hear; but (Deut. 5:5, 23-27) let not God speak with us, lest we die.”

And Moses said to the people, (Ex. 14:13; (Is. 41:10, 13)) “Do not fear; (Ex. 15:25; (Deut. 13:3)) for God has come to test you, and (Deut. 4:10; 6:24; Prov. 3:7; 16:6; Is. 8:13) that His fear may be before you, so that you may not sin.”
So the people stood afar off, but Moses drew near (Ex. 19:16; Deut. 5:22) the thick darkness where God was.
The Law of the Altar Then the LORD said to Moses, “Thus you shall say to the children of Israel: ‘You have seen that I have talked with you (Deut. 4:36; 5:24, 26; Neh. 9:13) from heaven.
You shall not make anything to be (Ex. 32:1, 2, 4; Deut. 29:17) with Me—gods of silver or gods of gold you shall not make for yourselves.

An altar of (Ex. 20:25; 27:1-8) earth you shall make for Me, and you shall sacrifice on it your burnt offerings and your peace offerings, (Ex. 24:5; Lev. 1:2) your sheep and your oxen. In every (Deut. 12:5; 16:6, 11; 1 Kin. 9:3; 2 Chr. 6:6) place where I record My name I will come to you, and I will (Gen. 12:2) bless you.
And (Deut. 27:5) if you make Me an altar of stone, you shall not build it of hewn stone; for if you (Josh. 8:30, 31) use your tool on it, you have profaned it.
Nor shall you go up by steps to My altar, that your (Ex. 28:42, 43) nakedness may not be exposed on it.’
The Law Concerning Servants “Now these are the judgments which you shall (Ex. 24:3, 4; Deut. 4:14; 6:1) set before them:
(Lev. 25:39-43; Deut. 15:12-18; Jer. 34:14) If you buy a Hebrew servant, he shall serve six years; and in the seventh he shall go out free and pay nothing.
If he comes in by himself, he shall go out by himself; if he comes in married, then his wife shall go out with him.
If his master has given him a wife, and she has borne him sons or daughters, the wife and her children shall be her master’s, and he shall go out by himself.
(Deut. 15:16, 17) But if the servant plainly says, ‘I love my master, my wife, and my children; I will not go out free,’

then his master shall bring him to the (Ex. 12:12; 22:8, 9) judges. He shall also bring him to the door, or to the doorpost, and his master shall pierce his ear with an awl; and he shall serve him forever.
“And if a man (Neh. 5:5) sells his daughter to be a female slave, she shall not go out as the male slaves do.

If she does not please her master, who has betrothed her to himself, then he shall let her be redeemed. He shall have no right to sell her to a foreign people, since he has dealt deceitfully with her.
And if he has betrothed her to his son, he shall deal with her according to the custom of daughters.
If he takes another wife, he shall not diminish her food, her clothing, ((1 Cor. 7:3, 5)) and her marriage rights.
And if he does not do these three for her, then she shall go out free, without paying money.
The Law Concerning Violence (Gen. 9:6; Lev. 24:17; Num. 35:30; (Matt. 26:52)) “He who strikes a man so that he dies shall surely be put to death.

However, (Deut. 19:4, 5) if he did not lie in wait, but God (1 Sam. 24:4, 10, 18) delivered him into his hand, then (Num. 35:11; Deut. 19:3; Josh. 20:2) I will appoint for you a place where he may flee.
“But if a man acts with (Deut. 19:11, 12; (Heb. 10:26)) premeditation against his neighbor, to kill him by treachery, (1 Kin. 2:28-34) you shall take him from My altar, that he may die.
“And he who strikes his father or his mother shall surely be put to death.
(Deut. 24:7) “He who kidnaps a man and (Gen. 37:28) sells him, or if he is (Ex. 22:4) found in his hand, shall surely be put to death.
“And (Lev. 20:9; Prov. 20:20; Matt. 15:4; Mark 7:10) he who curses his father or his mother shall surely be put to death.
“If men contend with each other, and one strikes the other with a stone or with his fist, and he does not die but is confined to his bed,

if he rises again and walks about outside (2 Sam. 3:29) with his staff, then he who struck him shall be acquitted. He shall only pay for the loss of his time, and shall provide for him to be thoroughly healed.
“And if a man beats his male or female servant with a rod, so that he dies under his hand, he shall surely be punished.
Notwithstanding, if he remains alive a day or two, he shall not be punished; for he is his (Lev. 25:44-46) property.

“If men fight, and hurt a woman with child, so that she gives birth prematurely, yet no harm follows, he shall surely be punished accordingly as the woman’s husband imposes on him; and he shall (Ex. 18:21, 22; 21:30; Deut. 22:18) pay as the judges determine.
But if any harm follows, then you shall give life for life,
(Lev. 24:20; Deut. 19:21; (Matt. 5:38-44; 1 Pet. 2:19-21)) eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot,
burn for burn, wound for wound, stripe for stripe.
“If a man strikes the eye of his male or female servant, and destroys it, he shall let him go free for the sake of his eye.
And if he knocks out the tooth of his male or female servant, he shall let him go free for the sake of his tooth.
